content.title: Deep Venous Reconstruction

definition.primary: Surgical procedures aimed at restoring venous outflow or competence in the deep venous system, primarily performed for post-thrombotic syndrome (PTS) with iliac vein obstruction, or for primary deep venous reflux refractory to conservative measures.
key_concepts: Includes both obstructive and reflux correction procedures
Iliac vein stenting has revolutionized treatment of outflow obstruction
Valve reconstruction addresses deep venous incompetence
Patient selection is critical for optimal outcomes

conditions: Post-thrombotic syndrome with iliac vein obstruction
clinical_criteria: Disabling limb swelling despite compression therapy
CEAP C5-C6 disease with deep reflux
Documented deep venous reflux on duplex

imaging.purpose: Assess reflux in deep veins, measure valve closure time (> 1 second is abnormal)
Evaluate iliac veins and IVC for obstruction
Gold standard for iliac vein assessment, identifies stenosis often missed on contrast venography
Traditional method, assess reflux severity and anatomy

hemodynamic_testing.purpose: Quantify venous function: venous filling index, ejection fraction, residual volume fraction

iliac_vein_stenting.description: Endovascular placement of dedicated venous stents to restore iliac vein patency

technique.access: Common femoral vein or popliteal vein access
technique.imaging: IVUS essential for accurate sizing and lesion assessment
technique.stent_selection: Dedicated venous stents (Wallstent, Venovo, Vici, Zilver Vena)
technique.sizing: Oversize by 1-2 mm to account for recoil
technique.extension: Extend to external iliac vein or femoral confluence, may extend into IVC

outcomes.patency: Primary patency 80-90% at 1 year, 70-80% at 3 years

palma_procedure.description: Saphenous vein crossover graft from contralateral side
palma_procedure.technique: GSV from unaffected side tunneled suprapubically to bypass obstruction
palma_procedure.adjunct: Often combined with distal AVF to maintain patency

may_husni_procedure.description: Saphenopopliteal bypass for femoral vein obstruction
may_husni_procedure.technique: GSV rerouted to bypass femoral vein obstruction

iliocaval_reconstruction.description: Ringed PTFE bypass for extensive iliocaval disease
iliocaval_reconstruction.indication: IVC or bilateral iliac vein obstruction
iliocaval_reconstruction.adjunct: Usually requires temporary AVF for patency

internal_valvuloplasty.description: Repair of native valve to restore competence

techniques.name: Kistner technique
techniques.description: Direct vision valve plication through venotomy
techniques.approach: Longitudinal venotomy, suture plication of redundant valve cusps

techniques.name: External valvuloplasty
techniques.description: External narrowing of vein to coapt valve cusps
techniques.approach: External sleeve or sutures without venotomy

internal_valvuloplasty.indications: Primary reflux with anatomically normal but floppy valves

valve_transplant.description: Transplantation of competent valve from axillary or brachial vein
valve_transplant.technique: Interposition of valve-containing venous segment into femoral vein

neovalve_construction.description: Creation of new valve from autologous tissue

anticoagulation.preoperative: Therapeutic anticoagulation in patients with prior DVT
anticoagulation.postoperative: Anticoagulation for 6-12 months minimum, often indefinite for stents
anticoagulation.agents: Warfarin or DOAC depending on indication

perioperative_management.surveillance: Duplex ultrasound at 1, 3, 6, 12 months then annually

content.statement: Deep Venous Reconstruction is a fundamental concept in Health-Sciences Medicine Surgery Vascular Pathology Deep-Venous that provides essential knowledge for understanding related topics and clinical/practical applications.

explanation.intuition: Understanding Deep Venous Reconstruction helps build foundational knowledge. The concept connects to broader principles in the field.
explanation.key_insight: The key aspects of Deep Venous Reconstruction include core principles, common applications, and integration with related concepts.
explanation.technical_details: Technical details involve specific mechanisms, measurements, and evidence-based applications of Deep Venous Reconstruction.

learning_objectives: Classify deep venous pathology into obstructive and reflux components
Determine appropriate diagnostic workup including IVUS
Select appropriate procedure based on pathology and anatomy
Understand outcomes and limitations of venous reconstruction
Apply appropriate anticoagulation and surveillance protocols
key_points: IVUS is essential for accurate iliac vein assessment
Dedicated venous stents have improved outcomes over arterial stents
Obstructive disease generally more treatable than isolated reflux
Valve reconstruction has modest long-term durability
Long-term anticoagulation required after venous stenting
clinical_pearls: Always evaluate iliac veins with IVUS - venography underestimates stenosis
May-Thurner is often an incidental finding - treat only if symptomatic
Combine superficial ablation with deep procedures for optimal results
Consider compression therapy trial before major reconstruction for reflux

key_guidelines.organization: Society for Vascular Surgery/American Venous Forum
